node.title: Accumulated Slip/Slip Increment
node.bodyText:
Hello,
In the previous crystal plasticity class(FiniteStraincrystalPlasticity), the accumulated slip was one of the variables for post-processing. I want to ask if it is the same as the slip increment in ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress. If not how do I get that? Thanks

Hello
I dont know but you can check
Use
[Debug]
  show_material_props = true
[]

and see if the quantity you want is available as a material property, and if so use an aux kernel and an aux variable to output it

node.title: Interfaces between a gap block and two blocks
node.bodyText:
All,
I am trying to generate interfaces between blocks and gap blocks to apply InterfaceKernels objets.
Please see attached "Interfaces between 2 blocks.pdf" for the procedure I am using.
Also, Attached "gapBTW2blocks_mesh.pdf" is the input script.
It is not working. Please help.  S. Thomas
Interfaces between 2 blocks.pdf
gapBTW2blocks_mesh.pdf

Hello
I m curious why you feel the need to introduce a gap block between domain 1 and 2.
Why cannot you use interface kernels directly at the interface between 1 and 2?
Guillaume

node.title: How to define a constant used in multiple expressions?
node.bodyText:
An general issue is that boudary width is a parameter in initial condition, and it also plays a role in expression defining interphase interfacial parameters (or, kappa in the tutorial). How can I use it in multiple expressions (or, something on the right of "=") so that I don't have to edit a bunch of numbers when I adjusting my model?
I tried GobalParams and GenericConstantMaterial in Materals, but failed to find the right syntax.
for example, my kappa is equal to 3 * sqrt(2) * int_width * other things, how can I achieve it in my input file?

Hello
You can do this at the top of the input file
kappa = '${fparse 3 * sqrt(2) * int_width * other things}'

then in the rest
[Some system]
  [some class]
    kappa = ${kappa}
...

Hmm...Actually my question is how to define 'int_width' in the input file.
Or just explain it in another way, I want to define an global constant x, and there is two parameter y=2x+1 and z=3x in different classes.
I wonder how to define x to ensure y and z correctly found it when defining.

Oh I may figure out how it works.
x = some value
and just don't put it in any system.
then
[Some system]  
  [some class]  
    y = 2 * ${x} + 1

It's kind of weird that there could be something put outside of any system.

it should be
    y = ${fparse 2 * x + 1}

the capability is documented. It's very useful
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/input_syntax.html

node.title: postprocessed variable values are zero at all timesteps, while solving a dynamic phase field fracture problem.
node.bodyText:
hi all,
i am trying to solve a dynamic phase field fracture problem.
geometry is a unit square plate, with right and left edges having roller supports. bottom edge is fixed, and a load is applied on the top edge. the load is varying with time.
i am running the files, and whatever i do the solution (postprocessed) values are zero at all timesteps, right from step one.
following are my input files:
main file:
E = 1000
nu = 0.3
K = '${fparse E/3/(1-2*nu)}'
G = '${fparse E/2/(1+nu)}'
Gc = 0.025
l = 0.1

[MultiApps]
    [fracture]
        type = TransientMultiApp
        input_files = prob3_fracture.i
        cli_args = 'Gc=${Gc};l=${l}'
        execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_END'
    []
[]

[Transfers]
    [from_d]
        type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
        from_multi_app = 'fracture'
        variable = d
        source_variable = d
    []
    [to_psie_active]
        type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
        to_multi_app = 'fracture'
        variable = psie_active
        source_variable = psie_active
    []
[]

[Mesh]
	type = FileMesh
	file = prob3.msh
[]

[GlobalParams]
  volumetric_locking_correction = false
  use_displaced_mesh = true
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'  
  order = FIRST
  family = LAGRANGE
[]

[Variables]
	[./disp_x]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
  	[../]
  	[./disp_y]
        order = FIRST
        family = LAGRANGE
  	[../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [dynamic_x]
	type = ADDynamicStressDivergenceTensors
    variable = disp_x
    component = 0
	zeta = 0
  []
  [dynamic_y]
	type = ADDynamicStressDivergenceTensors
    variable = disp_y
    component = 1
	zeta = 0
  []
  [inertia_x]
    type = ADInertialForce
    variable = disp_x
	density = density
	eta = 0
  []
  [inertia_y]
    type = ADInertialForce
    variable = disp_y
	density = density
	eta = 0
  []
[]

[AuxVariables] 
    [fx]
    []
    [fy]
    []
    [d]
    []
  	[./accel_x]
  	[../]
  	[./vel_x]
  	[../]
  	[./accel_y]
  	[../]
  	[./vel_y]
  	[../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
	[./acceleration_x]
    type = TestNewmarkTI
    variable = accel_x
    displacement = disp_x
    first = false
  [../]
  [./velocity_x]
    type = TestNewmarkTI
    variable = vel_x
    displacement = disp_x
  [../]
  [./acceleration_y]
    type = TestNewmarkTI
    variable = accel_y
    displacement = disp_y
    first = false
  [../]
  [./velocity_y]
    type = TestNewmarkTI
    variable = vel_y
    displacement = disp_y
  [../]
[]		

[Functions]
	[./load]
		type = PiecewiseLinear
		x = '0 	0.05 0.1'
		y = '0 	1    1'
	[../]
[]
  
[BCs]
	[./roller_left]
		type = ADDirichletBC
		variable = disp_x
		boundary = left
		value = 0
	[../]
    [./roller_right]
		type = ADDirichletBC
		variable = disp_x
		boundary = right
		value = 0
	[../]			
	[.fix_y]
		type = ADDirichletBC
		variable = disp_y
		boundary = bottom
		value = 0
	[../]
	[.fix_x]
		type = ADDirichletBC
		variable = disp_x
		boundary = bottom
		value = 0
	[../]
	[./traction]
		type = ADPressure
		variable = 'disp_y'
		boundary = 'top'
		function = load
		factor = -1
	[../]
[]

[Materials]
    [bulk]
        type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
        prop_names = 'K G'
        prop_values = '${K} ${G}'
    []
    [./density]
		type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
		prop_names = density
		prop_values = 1
	[../]
    [degradation]
        type = PowerDegradationFunction
        f_name = g
        function = (1-d)^p*(1-eta)+eta
        phase_field = d
        parameter_names = 'p eta'
        parameter_values = '2 0'
    []
    [strain]
        type = ADComputeSmallStrain
    []
    [elasticity]
        type = SmallDeformationIsotropicElasticity
        bulk_modulus = K
        shear_modulus = G
        phase_field = d
        degradation_function = g
        decomposition = NONE
        output_properties = 'elastic_strain psie_active'
        outputs = exodus
    []
    [stress]
        type = ComputeSmallDeformationStress
        elasticity_model = elasticity
        output_properties = 'stress'
        outputs = exodus
    []
[]

[Executioner]
	type = Transient
    solve_type = NEWTON
    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
    petsc_options_value = 'lu       superlu_dist                 '
    automatic_scaling = true
    nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
    nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
    start_time = 0
    dt = 0.005 
    end_time = 0.1
    fixed_point_max_its = 10
    fixed_point_min_its = 2
    accept_on_max_fixed_point_iteration = true
    fixed_point_rel_tol = 1e-8
    fixed_point_abs_tol = 1e-10
         [TimeIntegrator]
            type = NewmarkBeta
            beta = 0.25
            gamma = 0.5
        []
[]

[Postprocessors]
	[./y_disp]
		type = NormalBoundaryDisplacement
    	#displacements = disp_y
    	boundary = top
    	value_type = absolute_max
  	[../]
    [./phi]
        type = AverageNodalVariableValue
        variable = d
    [../]
[]

[VectorPostprocessors]
	[./y_disp_and_d]
		type = LineValueSampler
		start_point = '0.5 0 0'
		end_point = '0.5 1 0'
		num_points = 51
		variable = 'disp_y d'
		sort_by = y
		contains_complete_history = true
	[../]
[]

fracture file:
[Mesh]
  type = FileMesh
  file = prob3.msh
[]

[Variables]
  [d]
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [bounds_dummy]
  []
  [psie_active]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[Bounds]
  [irreversibility]
    type = VariableOldValueBoundsAux
    variable = bounds_dummy
    bounded_variable = d
    bound_type = lower
  []
  [upper]
    type = ConstantBoundsAux
    variable = bounds_dummy
    bounded_variable = d
    bound_type = upper
    bound_value = 1
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [diff]
    type = ADPFFDiffusion
    variable = d
    fracture_toughness = Gc
    regularization_length = l
    normalization_constant = c0
  []
  [source]
    type = ADPFFSource
    variable = d
    free_energy = psi
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [fracture_properties]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'Gc l'
    prop_values = '${Gc} ${l}'
  []
  [./density]
		type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
		prop_names = density
		prop_values = 1
	[../]

  [degradation]
    type = PowerDegradationFunction
    f_name = g
    function = (1-d)^p*(1-eta)+eta
    phase_field = d
    parameter_names = 'p eta'
    parameter_values = '2 0'
  []
  [crack_geometric]
    type = CrackGeometricFunction
    f_name = alpha
    function = 'd^2'
    phase_field = d
  []
  [psi]
    type = ADDerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = psi
    function = 'alpha*Gc/c0/l+g*psie_active'
    args = 'd psie_active'
    material_property_names = 'alpha(d) g(d) Gc c0 l'
    derivative_order = 1
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient

  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package -snes_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       superlu_dist                  vinewtonrsls'
  automatic_scaling = true

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-10
[]

[Outputs]
  print_linear_residuals = true
[]

i have ensured that the length scale is 5 times the mesh element size.
what have i missed?

hello
which postprocesing is 0 at all timesteps?
the postprcoessors or the vectorpostprocessor?
Is the sub-app giving reasonable results on its own?
Guillaume

both postprocessor and vectorpostprocessor are zero at all times.
how should i check the sub-app results?

you can try

running the subapp input only
or
adding outputs to the subapp and checking those

i added the following block to my sub app input file:
[Postprocessors]
	[./phi_sub_app]
        type = AverageNodalVariableValue
        variable = d
    [../]
[]

still, it's the same issue. postprocessed values are zero at all timesteps.

ok. And you're confident phi_sub_app should not amount to 0? At the end of the time steps you are examining.
Are you looking at the value in the console or in an output csv file?

yes, since i am applying a load on top edge, there should be some evolution of phase field parameter, and there should be gradual increase in displacement too as the load ramps with time. i am looking at both console and csv outputs.
i think there is a problem with the time integrator block. for some reason there is no communication between the main and sub apps. i am not sure what is the reason for this.

you can use Problem/verbose_multiapps = true to see the transfers happen.
The only reasons I could see for this are:

the solve is failing completely and the fields are not updating. you should see this in the log
you are looking at the wrong CSV. Either an old one or the one output on initial conditions
something is overwriting d in the main app, I dont see an auxkernel doing that
a bug in the VPP, likely because of "contains_complete_history" which is not always implemented

Hello

You need to recompile with the phase field module I think
You add this in the makefile
As I am new to this environment, can you explain how I can do this?

The Makefile should be in the root folder of your application.
Once you open it with a text editor, you can see the list of modules compiled with your application.
SmoothCircleIC is in the phase_field module, so add 'YES' in front of that module
PHASE_FIELD                 := yes

then make clobberall then recompile

Thanks for your help.
Makefile shows this item was sat to "yes" but still the same error is there. Is there any other way to solve this?

Unfortunately you do need to clean the repo and recompile between having it set to 'no' and set to 'yes'
so
cd ~/projects/<name of the app>
git commit -am "saving everything"
git clean -xfD
make -j 6

Thanks for your help. I sat it to 'no' and then ran the comments you provided, then I sat it again to 'yes' and again ran the provided comments. After that, still the error is there. Was what I did correct?

Weird.
You could try cleaning moose too, not that it should be needed.
cd ~/projects/moose
git clean -xfd
cd ~/project/your_app
make -j 6

Else a fresh clone could help.

After several trials, I could add phase field module. Now, I need to add solid mechanics as well but I was not enable to it. I tried previous comments that you suggested but it did not work. No phase filed module works but solid mechanics no!
Can you help me with this?

hello
the procedure is the same for both modules.
once added in the makefile, you commit that, then clean everything, then re-build

node.title: Question of loop simulation in PWR using THM
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I'm simulating a very simple PWR loop using THM. The loop does not contain the heat source. The distribution of pressure and velocity is shown below.


The input file is simple_pwr_loop.txt.
As in typical PWR, the pressure drop through the pump should be 0.5MPa, which is good in this simulation. But the velocity in the loop should be 5m/s. In this simulation, it is only 0.5 m/s. I do not know the reason.
I tried to change the area of the pipe, but the results did not change.
I also tried to increase the pump head, which could result in an increase in velocity, but following the pressure drop also increased rapidly.
How to let the pressure drop keep at  0.5MPa, and increase the velocity to 5m/s at the same time?
Thanks!

Hi @GiudGiud @joshuahansel,
Could you please kindly give me some suggestions?
Thanks!

How to let the pressure drop keep at 0.5MPa, and increase the velocity to 5m/s at the same time?

Not sure there is an easy solution there. The pressure drop is tied to the velocity since it partially comes from friction. You could mess with the pipe friction factors, maybe use a different model for the roughness, to reduce pressure drop. The area of the pipe is a variable as well.
Maybe plot the results of pressure_drop as a function of velocity and see if some part of the curve works for you

Hi,
I try to let the f_factor of all pipe equal to 0, since I just use the simple closures. But nothing changed.
Also, I have tried to change the area of all pipe, it can not change the result. Because the pump area and the pipe area are same.
So, I think both the pipe friction factors and area of pipe are not the key parameters to fix this problem.
I searched some reference: Andrs D, Berry R, Gaston D, et al. Relap-7 level 2 milestone report: Demonstration of a steady state single phase pwr simulation with relap-7[R]. Idaho National Lab.(INL), Idaho Falls, ID (United States), 2012.


The results of RELAP7 could let the pressure drop keep at 0.5MPa, and increase the velocity to 5m/s at the same time. I still have no idea to fix this problem.

It appears you are not running close to a steady state. I see that the pressure drops sharply at the junction of your loop with the pressurizer, and this is overshadowing any of the other pressure drops in your system, like by gravity and friction. Running longer decreases this pressure drop. See if you can get to steady state. Perhaps you can try ramping the pump head from zero to your end value to ease the transient.
Ultimately, your pressure drops in your loop need to sum to your pump head. Contributions will be from friction, junctions, and gravity, so your ability to change the steady velocity will be based on the friction factor, since that's the only one you can change.

Hi, thanks for your suggestion!
I tried to simulate this case for a long time (5000s) and tried to use a function of the pump head from zero to my needed value. But nothing changed. The pressure drop at the junction connected with the pressurizer is still sharp. Also, the value of the velocity in the loop did not change.

I don't know if 5000 s is long enough. I recall seeing the pressure still changing long after that. For example, do something like
  end_time = 1000000
  [TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 10
    optimal_iterations = 5
    iteration_window = 0
    growth_factor = 1.2
    cutback_factor = 0.8
  []
  steady_state_detection = true

Another factor here is your junction volumes - try modifying those to see how that changes things.

I ran for 100000 seconds now. I found that the velocity can not increase but decreases by about 0.2 m/s. How can the velocity be increased to 5 m/s? The only thing I could change is the pump head to increase the velocity.

Another factor here is your junction volumes - try modifying those to see how that changes things.

I have tried this way, the result would same after a long time.

Ok, I'm thinking that this may be a deficiency in the volume junction formulation. I tried putting another pipe connected to the upper left junction with a dead end (wall) instead of an inlet, and it introduced a similar sharp pressure drop across the junction. I've been struggling all day to try and come up with some improvement to this junction formulation but haven't made progress.
One test you could try would be to put all of your loop pipes in the x-direction and have the pressurizer pipe be orthogonal. The issue appears to be the change of direction coupled with having a connection of more than 2 pipes. Note that the "gravity_vector" parameter can be modified per pipe so that you can get all of the gravity effects correct. Note this is not a long-term solution but just a test.

Thank you for your time!

One test you could try would be to put all of your loop pipes in the x-direction and have the pressurizer pipe be orthogonal.

Ok, I will have a try.
By the way, if you figure out this problem in a good way, please do not hesitate to tell me. And I will also try to find the right way and try my best to improve it.
Thanks!!

I looked into this more, and on more consideration, I'm not sure that the junction is doing anything wrong. Some kind of pressure drop there is reasonable to me if the pressure losses downstream of the pump cannot match produce the pressurizer's pressure.
Increasing the pump head does in fact increase the velocity in the loop. However, you have an issue with your problem: your setup will just continually heat up your fluid in your loop forever, since you have no heat sink, decreasing the density and thus your pump head will be equivalent to a lower pressure drop over time. As for the pressure drop across your pressurizer junction, I think you're going to see that as long as your pressure losses between pump outlet and pressurizer are not large enough.

Thank you for your suggestions and your time!

your setup will just continually heat up your fluid in your loop forever, since you have no heat sink, decreasing the density and thus your pump head will be equivalent to a lower pressure drop over time.

I added the heat source of pipe1 (increasing the coolant temperature from 564 to 600 K) and set the HeatTransferFromSpecifiedTemperature1Phase(564 K) to pipe3, which is the typical condition in PWR. Now, I can get a steady reasult.


the pressure losses downstream of the pump cannot match produce the pressurizer's pressure

Then I changed a new friction factor (100000) in pipe1 and pipe2, which is large enough to let the pressure close to the pressure of the pressurize. There are no large pressure drop at the junction of pressurize. That's good.

However, the velocity decreased to 0.08 m/s since I introduced a lot of frictional drag into the momentum equation in pipe1 and pipe2.

We still have not solved this problem. How do we keep these conditions (pressure and temperature distribution) and just increase the loop velocity to 5m/s? I'm still confused.
Here is the new input file.
loop.txt
Thanks!

I wouldn't necessarily adjust the friction factor to eliminate that pressure drop at the junction. Just model your system as closely as you're able to your actual reference system:

Have your input power/heat sink as close as for your BWR case
Have your friction factor estimated according to some correlation appropriate for your BWR
Have your piping length system match as well as you can, including the length and flow area
Increase pump head until you get to 5 m/s
Thanks!

node.title: Time dependent BCs
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello, I have some problems understanding and implementing a Boundary condition that varies with time. I need a  Dirichlet Boundary condition that goes from a to b (for example 0 to 1). I found that MOOSE does have this function in terms of "FunctionDirichletBC" however I need help with the syntax and formatting of the function.
As background I specifically want Voltage (V) to vary with time only and apply it to the top edge of a 2D mesh, going from 0 up to 1 and then back down to 0 linearly. To apply said BC would it be sufficient to add this block:
[BCs]
  [./V_top]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = V
    boundary = 'top'
    function = - abs(t - 1) + 1
  [../]
[] 

Does MOOSE recognise t to be time? I noticed there is also the PiecewiseLinear function that could be added, would I have to instead create a different function block with an input .cvs and then link that to the function input of the FunctionDirichletBC shown above?

Hello
There are numerous ways to input these functions, the PiecewiseLinear would work too. I believe
function = '- abs(t - 1) + 1'

will already get parsed automatically into a function of time.
If not, then you can use a ParsedFunction f and specify function = f in that object.
For f you will have
[Functions]
  [f]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '- abs(t - 1) + 1'
  []
[]

Thank you very much, it did indeed seem to work. I would also like to output the voltage into a CVS file, As a way to double check, how would I add that to the input file/what documentation exists that would lead me to implement this?

you can output functions to console and csv with this object
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/FunctionValuePostprocessor.html

node.title: Basal-prismatic slip systems Crystal Plasticity
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I have a doubt on crystal plasticity considering multiple slip systems. I have 2 material phases of which the first is BCC and the second one is HCP. I should simulate sliding on both the basal and prismatic slip planes of the alpha (hcp) phase using CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate which have different hardening paremeters. At this point, I've tried modelling as two different slip systems as two distinct phases using base_name but I get errors but maybe I'm not using it correctly. Do you have any suggestions? Should I modify the CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate or is there another way to do it?
Thanks,
Paolo
@laagesen
I would ask for help from @sapitts or @parikshitbajpai or @dewenyushu on this one for crystal plasticity

I would ask for help from @sapitts or @parikshitbajpai or @dewenyushu on this one for crystal plasticity

I think you meant @vprithiv
yes sorry about that!

@p-antonioni
One way to approach this problem is to define two different blocks for those two phases and specify them in the material blocks, this potentially should work without changing anything in the code
Just an example below (make sure to use the actual objects)
[elasticity_phase1]
type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
youngs_modulus = 1
poissons_ratio = 0.1
block = 'phase1'
[]
[elasticity_phase2]
type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
youngs_modulus = 2
poissons_ratio = 0.2
block = 'phase2'
[]

@p-antonioni in case you have not already resolved this issue, there is a specific HCP class available in MOOSE, see https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/crystal_plasticity/CrystalPlasticityHCPDislocationSlipBeyerleinUpdate.html I would recommend using this HCP specific class over modifications to the Kalidindi class if you are still having issues.

@sapitts I would like to know if the "ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress" or "CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate" can be modified to compute other crystal structures aside from FCC or cubic and How can I do that?

ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress is the "calling" stress class that has to be used for any and all crystal plasticity constitutive models. The CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate class is purpose built for FCC, 12 slip systems --you can see the hard coded assumptions we transferred from the cited papers in the source class construction of the hardening matrix: https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/solid_mechanics/src/materials/crystal_plasticity/CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate.C#L176-L191. If you wanted to modify this class to more generally handle additional slip systems, these are the lines where I would make the modification (possibly among other modifications).
Outside of the HCP specific class referenced above, we do not have the constitutive models for non-FCC crystals currently in MOOSE. There are active research projects on-going with more flexibility for additional numbers of slip systems and/or cubic structures, but none of these efforts have yet reached the maturity necessary to be merged into MOOSE. It is the goal to merge these in-development constitutive models into MOOSE in the future--and we welcome pull requests from our users!

@p-antonioni Please accept my apologies for my delay in responding--I am not able to monitor the discussion pages as frequently as I would like. I'd probably lean more towards a simplifying modification of the HCP model because it should handle the different slip planes and latent hardening within the single class.
In case it is still of use to you in your research with the Kalidindi model, you may be able to pass some element of hardening (really the deformation) through the deformation gradient--we take this approach in the calculation of the crystal plasticity eigenstrains, see https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/modules/solid_mechanics/src/materials/crystal_plasticity/CrystalPlasticityStressUpdateBase.C#L413-L435
